Award.AwardTitle: ABI Innovation: Collaborative Research: Computational framework for inference of metabolic pathway activity from RNA-seq data
Award.AbstractNarration:
Microbial communities, or microbiomes, are an essential part of life on Earth. Microbiomes in the natural environment, including those associated with animals and plants, have thousands of interacting microbial species. Microbial communities influence key aspects of host health and behavior. They drive basic biochemical processes in their hosts, such as nutrient processing in the guts and sequestration of carbon in the Earth's oceans. The study of microbiomes has been recently revolutionized by the use of advanced sequencing technologies. However, large-scale sequencing initiatives, such as the Human Microbiome Project and the Earth Microbiome Project, are generating Petabytes (10 to the power of 15 bytes) of data, more than existing analysis tools can handle. The goal of this project is to develop transformative computational methods and implement software tools that enable the analysis of these very large datasets. Specifically, these tools will provide improved methods to organize community gene expression data (metatranscriptomes) into metabolic pathways, which informs predictions of how biochemical processes transform matter and energy. To maximize its impact, the developed software tools will be made available to the research community as stand-alone open source packages and deployed on common cloud computing environments. The project will provide opportunities for mentoring undergraduate and graduate students at Georgia State University, University of Connecticut, and Georgia Tech and promote participation of women and underrepresented groups in bioinformatics research and empirical analysis of community-level sequence (DNA/RNA) datasets. Selected aspects of the proposed research will be incorporated in courses at the three universities, and form the basis of innovative curriculum and educational materials, including the creation of mobile applications.

This project brings together an interdisciplinary team of computer scientists and environmental microbiologists to develop and implement computational tools that enable de novo analysis of large multi-sample microbiome sequencing datasets, addressing current challenges in metatranscriptome assembly and inference of metabolic pathway activity. Specific aims of the project include: (i) developing highly scalable algorithms for de novo assembly and quantification from multiple metatranscriptomic samples, (ii) developing highly accurate algorithms for estimation of metabolic pathway activity level and differential activity testing, (iii) developing and validating prototype implementations of developed methods. A distinguishing feature of the developed methods will be their ability to jointly analyze multiple related metatranscriptomic samples. This joint assembly and quantification paradigm is likely to find applications beyond microbiome research, e.g., in the emerging area of single cell genomics. The results of the project, including software packages, research publications, and educational materials, will be made available at http://alan.cs.gsu.edu/NGS/?q=software and http://dna.engr.uconn.edu/?page_id=719

POR.DRECONTENT:
At the broadest level, this project focused on improving the tools we use to understand the diversity and metabolic activity of microbial communities. Accurate and standardized characterization of microbial communities is critical for predicting changes in the microbial transformations of matter and energy in diverse ecosystems. These ecosystems can include the human body, and the microbes therein, as well as much larger systems, such as oceans or terrestrial biomes. Characterizing how microbiomes affect matter and energy flow in these systems enables an understanding of how to maintain ecosystem heath, which has direct effects on human well­being as well as the integrity of diverse economic and recreational activities. 

The specific goal of this project was to develop, implement, and validate computational tools that enable de novo analysis of large multi-sample microbiome sequencing datasets (RNA and DNA) and simultaneously address current challenges in metatranscriptome (community RNA sequences) assembly and inference of metabolic pathway activity. Aims included: (i) developing highly scalable algorithms for de novo assembly and quantification from multiple metatranscriptomic samples, (ii) developing highly accurate algorithms for estimation of metabolic pathway activity level and differential activity testing, (iii) developing and validating prototype implementations of developed methods. 

The Stewart and Lopanik labs at Georgia Tech were responsible primarily for aim III by comparing the newly developed algorithms and existing pathway annotation tools and differential expression tests using microbiome metatranscriptome datasets from environmental samples. This project relied extensively on meta-omic data from a marine oxygen minimum zone (OMZ), from diverse habitats at Georgia Aquarium, and from various host-associated microbiome communities. Together, these datasets, in addition to enabling testing of the tools developed in this grant, constitute important resources for the user community, notably because many natural and engineered environments (such as these) are still relatively undercharacterized from the perspective of environmental genomics and because knowledge of how host association structures microbial composition and function is critical for understanding animal health. In analyzing these datasets to test the algorithms at the core of this grant, we generated a total of 11 peer-reviewed publications.  These papers provide insight into the diversity and ecological function of microbial communities in nature.  All sequence data generated in this project has been made publicly available, along with supporting environmental metadata. All papers acknowledge NSF support (grant 1564559).

A second major goal of this project was to provide training and leadership opportunities to students and postdocs.  Funding from this grant has directly or indirectly supported multiple graduate students, a postdoc, and the co-PIs (Lopanik, Stewart). The postdoc, a young female scientist, will soon be starting (2020) a prestigious fellowship program at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.  Her success is a direct result of resources provided by this grant. 

The tools resulting from this work will be of interest to anyone using meta-omic data to characterize microbial communities. This includes scientists in the fields of human health, environmental microbiology, biogeochemistry, ecology, and forensics. The sample processing and analytical pipelines developed and used in this grant require next generation sequencing technology and data analysis, and therefore create opportunities for training in the field of molecular biology in general, as well as the production of environmental sequence datasets that can serve as a valuable reference for comparative studies by other researchers.
